pages.text: Ovatoscutum concentricum comes from the Upper Ediacaran, with fossils from the White Sea, Russia and Flinders Ranges, South Australia. It is a round, quilted lifeform that was able to move around in order to get food, and could grow up to 6 cm in diameter. It is the most rounded of any Proarticulata known, with this being a cause for discussion on whether it was an hydrozoan when discovered, although recent studies place it within the Proarticulata Phylum.
The generic name derives from the Latin words 'ovatus', to mean 'oval' and 'scutum', to mean 'shield'. The specific name derives from the latin word 'concentricus'.
